# dmerg

Command line utility to merge the standard output and the kernel ring buffer.

## Example

```
test@test:~$ for i in {1..100}; do echo $i; sleep 2; done | ./dmerg
2021-09-13T17:26:51,513596590+00:00 1
2021-09-13T17:26:53,514150509+00:00 2
2021-09-13T17:26:55,517686572+00:00 3
2021-09-13T17:26:53,692321+00:00 Unloaded Memory Tracer
2021-09-13T17:26:53,701446+00:00 Memory Tracer
2021-09-13T17:26:54,451349+00:00 Unloaded Memory Tracer
2021-09-13T17:26:54,459408+00:00 Memory Tracer
2021-09-13T17:26:57,521304701+00:00 4
2021-09-13T17:26:59,524629559+00:00 5
2021-09-13T17:27:01,528291248+00:00 6
^C
+ Output written to result_5kZwA1jpU0A1qaJ0FigW5fZVrXJxay

test@test:~$ cat result_5kZwA1jpU0A1qaJ0FigW5fZVrXJxay
2021-09-13T17:26:51,513596590+00:00 1
2021-09-13T17:26:53,514150509+00:00 2
2021-09-13T17:26:53,692321+00:00 Unloaded Memory Tracer
2021-09-13T17:26:53,701446+00:00 Memory Tracer
2021-09-13T17:26:54,451349+00:00 Unloaded Memory Tracer
2021-09-13T17:26:54,459408+00:00 Memory Tracer
2021-09-13T17:26:55,517686572+00:00 3
2021-09-13T17:26:57,521304701+00:00 4
2021-09-13T17:26:59,524629559+00:00 5
2021-09-13T17:27:01,528291248+00:00 6
```
